frequency.title: Frequency
frequency.description: The pitch of the sound measured in Hertz (Hz).
frequency.tips: Try 440 Hz for a reference tone, or 261.6 Hz for middle C.

waveform.title: Waveform
waveform.description: The shape of the sound wave determines its timbre (tone color).
details: Sine: Pure tone, smooth and mellow (flute-like)
Square: Hollow, clarinet-like sound with odd harmonics
Sawtooth: Bright, rich sound with all harmonics (strings, brass)
Triangle: Softer than square, mellow (similar to sine but richer)
waveform.tips: Start with sine for pure tones, sawtooth for richer sounds.

duration.title: Duration
duration.description: How long the sound plays in seconds.
details: Shorter durations work well for percussion
Combined with envelope for total control
duration.tips: Use 0.2-0.5s for short hits, 1-2s for sustained tones.

volume.title: Volume
details: Volume of 0.0 marks the layer as blank/unset
Combine multiple layers: reduce individual volumes to avoid clipping
volume.tips: Start at 0.7 for single layers, 0.3-0.5 for multiple layers.

overlap.title: Overlap
overlap.description: How much the next layer starts before this one finishes.
details: Positive values: next layer starts early (overlap)
overlap.tips: Try 0.1-0.3s for smooth transitions, 0.0 for distinct separation.

attack.title: Attack Time
attack.description: How quickly the sound reaches full volume after starting.
attack.tips: Use 0.01s for drums, 0.1s for plucked strings, 0.3s+ for pads.

decay.title: Decay Time
decay.description: How quickly the sound drops from peak to sustain level.
decay.tips: Match to your sustain level for desired character.

sustain.title: Sustain Level
sustain.description: The volume level held after decay, before release.
details: Not a time value - it's an amplitude level
sustain.tips: Use 0.7+ for sustained instruments, 0.1-0.3 for plucked sounds.

release.title: Release Time
release.description: How long the sound takes to fade to silence after the note ends.
release.tips: Use 0.5-1.0s for realistic acoustic sounds, 0.1s for electronic hits.

harmonics.title: Harmonics
harmonics.description: Add additional frequencies to create richer, more complex tones.
details: Octave: Adds a note one octave (double frequency) above
Fifth: Adds the musical fifth interval above the octave
Sub-bass: Adds a note one octave below (half frequency)
Volumes are relative to the main tone
harmonics.tips: Start with octave at 0.3-0.5 for richness without overwhelming.

fm_ratio.title: FM Modulator Ratio
fm_ratio.description: The frequency relationship between carrier and modulator in FM synthesis.
details: Non-integer ratios create inharmonic, bell-like tones
fm_ratio.tips: Experiment! Small changes create dramatically different timbres.

fm_index.title: FM Modulation Index
fm_index.description: Controls how much the modulator affects the carrier frequency.
details: High index (6-10): Complex, bright, aggressive tones
fm_index.tips: Start with 3-5 for musical sounds, go higher for aggressive tones.

noise_type.title: Noise Type
noise_type.description: The spectral distribution of random noise.
details: White: Equal energy at all frequencies (hiss, cymbals, hi-hats)
Pink: More energy in lower frequencies (ocean, rain, wind)
Brown: Even more bass energy (thunder, rumble, explosions)
Each type has a different 'color' or frequency balance
noise_type.tips: White for percussion, pink for nature sounds, brown for low rumble.

noise_filter.title: Noise Filter
noise_filter.description: Shapes noise by allowing only certain frequencies to pass through.
details: Bandpass: Allows frequencies between low and high cutoffs
Highpass: Allows only frequencies above the low cutoff
Lowpass: Allows only frequencies below the high cutoff
Create snare drums, hi-hats, wind effects
noise_filter.tips: Bandpass 2000-8000 Hz on white noise = hi-hat sound.

lfo.title: LFO (Low Frequency Oscillator) Tremolo
lfo.description: Creates rhythmic volume variations for vibrato/tremolo effects.
details: LFO Frequency: How fast the volume oscillates (0.5-10 Hz)
LFO Depth: How much the volume changes (0-100%)
Low freq (1-3 Hz): Slow, sweeping tremolo
High freq (5-8 Hz): Rapid vibrato effect
Used in guitar amps, synthesizers, organs
lfo.tips: Try 5 Hz at 30% depth for classic tremolo effect.

echo.title: Echo / Delay
echo.description: Creates repeating copies of the sound at regular intervals.
details: Delay Time: Gap between original and echo (0.05-1.0s)
Feedback: How much each echo repeats (0-90%)
echo.tips: Try 0.3s delay with 40% feedback for a natural echo.
